instruction: How were the machine learning models trained and optimized to estimate the combustion properties of jet fuels and hydrocarbon species using FTIR spectra?
Output: The machine learning models were trained and optimized using a strategy that leveraged the gas-phase Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra of pure hydrocarbons and jet fuels in the 2-15.38 渭m wavelength range. Elastic-net regularized linear models were employed, with separate optimization of model parameters for each combustion property (ignition delay time, net heat of combustion, and derived cetane number). The training process involved utilizing the strong sensitivity of combustion behavior to the different infrared absorption features of hydrocarbon fuels. The models' performance was compared to previous models that only utilized a limited spectral region in the wavelength range of 3.3-3.55 渭m. The new, optimized models demonstrated significant improvement in predictive performance for all three properties compared to the previous models. The models' prediction errors on test data, which included blends of conventional and alternative jet fuels, were found to be comparable to the standard measurement uncertainties of the properties. This highlights the effectiveness of infrared spectral analysis as a low-volume prescreening tool for accurate estimation of combustion properties in both conventional and alternative jet fuels.

instruction: How does the predictive performance of the optimized models using infrared spectral analysis compare to traditional methods for estimating combustion properties of jet fuels and hydrocarbon species?
Output: The predictive performance of the optimized models using infrared spectral analysis is significantly better compared to traditional methods for estimating combustion properties of jet fuels and hydrocarbon species. The previous models, which utilized only a limited spectral region, have been outperformed by the new optimized models developed in this work. The new models show significant improvement in predictive performance for all three properties: ignition delay time (IDT), net heat of combustion (NHC), and derived cetane number (DCN). The prediction errors of the optimized models on test data (blends of conventional and alternative jet fuels) are found to be comparable to the standard property measurement uncertainties. This demonstrates the value of infrared spectral analysis as a low-volume prescreening tool for accurate property estimation of both conventional and alternative jet fuels.
